Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2009 12:51PM - edited Jan 16, 2009 12:52PM by elizzim I think my very recent experience should be helpful to you right now:  I just had (Jan. 6th, 2009) bilateral mastectomy with insertion of tissue expanders. First of all, let me state at the outset that NO ONE COULD BE VAINER THAN I!! I always loved my breasts, and while my desire to live a long life with my 2 wonderful daughters outweighs everything, the idea of losing my breasts was devastating to me.  I won't go into the reasons that I opted for a BM here, but I will say that I found out post-op that there had been DCIS in the "healthy" breast, which was sobering news and told me I made the right decision.  I bring that up here because - while everyone's experience is different - it might be thought-provoking for you. But the main thing is: while I was so devastated by the idea of losing my breasts - I feel SO HAPPY with the results already, that I know the final result will be absolutely FINE.  I think the key is to use the BEST surgeon and reconstructive surgeon that you can find.  My plastic surgeon did such a beautiful job with my nipple-sparing mastectomies, that I can already see my new breasts taking form, and they are amazing.  Be careful looking at pictures on the internet: there is a wide range in technical expertise among reconstructive surgeons, scars do fade over time, and it can all look scarier than it needs to be.  If you find an excellent surgical team, you can look forward to surprisingly nice results.  All of this is, of course, in the context of doing all you can to save your life!! Feel free to ask me any specific questions - I have no modesty left!  But keep in mind that I, too, am new to this whole world.  There are so many others here who have much more experience with the whole process. -Liz
Posts.Title: I am so confused as to which route to take jancie Beesie

Posts.Content: elizzim wrote: Hi all- I am a reluctant but comforted new member - recluctant because I've been dreading this diagnosis my entire life (my mom died of BC), and comforted because there's so much courage, spirit and support here.  I was diagnosed w/IDC (via stereotactic biopsy) in early December, and am scheduled for a Bilateral Mastectomy & insertion of tissue expanders on January 6th.  I am a divorced (single for all practical purposes) mother of two beautiful girls, ages 10 and 7.  I think I'm doing pretty well with all this in terms of outward appearances, but inside I'm terrified.  Mostly of leaving my kids one day, much sooner than they need me to, but also of the short term challenges of surgery, recuperation, and adjuvant treatments.  Can anyone give me a realistic picture of what the recovery from my upcoming surgery will be like?  Do I need help in the house, or can I do it on my own (i.e. preparing simple things to eat, etc.)? I've focused so much on having people there for my daughters, that I've not focused at all on the care I could need post-op.  I'd appreciate any guidance that anyone could give me. Thanks for the comfort and support that all of you give those of us who don't know where to turn. Liz  Liz Dx 12/9/2008, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/8 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2009 01:23PM elizzim wrote: Heidi has touched so many of us here. She will truly live on forever, and continue to inspire us in our own journeys. Heidi, can you hear us clapping for you?
Posts.Title: Heidi Update-it isn't pretty Heidi_Ho zeeka71

Posts.Content: elizzim wrote: Yesterday, I had the privilege of attending Heidi's memorial service. Although this is the first time I've had an opportunity to post, I've thought of little else since. For all of the love we feel for Heidi on this site, for our sense of her sparkle and her grace, we could not have begun to imagine the person she was. I am a different person today than I was before I attended her memorial. Seeing Heidi come to life in the words and stories of those who shared her life, I fell in love. And I understood what "a life well lived" truly means. Often after a memorial service - even after the beautiful memorials of people close to me - I have felt that while the service gave comfort to those who attended, it didn't begin to do justice to the life and the unique soul being celebrated. But at Heidi's service, it was quite the opposite. The love that she created in her life and the imprint of her spirit on those close to her were so vivid and alive that it was as though she was there in the room. Through the words and the stories of her husband, father, and her closest friends, I came to know a woman who understood what makes life precious, and whose every act and expression was a reflection of that. She was funny, honest, loving, and totally genuine. She showed the people around her how much she loved them, she shared herself without censorship. She brought her friends together, made the moments they shared insanely fun, made each moment meaningful and created the life that she desired, instead of waiting for life and circumstances to shape her. Hearing her friends describe their life with Heidi, it was clear that without her, each of them would be missing a part of themselves. The pain that they feel without her here was palpable. From listening to Heidi's friends, I have a new understanding of what friendship is, and what I want to give to those closest to me. Even in the gorgeous pictures of her that surrounded us, Heidi simply radiated light. She loved her family - her husband and beautiful children, her brother and parents - selflessly and without inhibition. As I looked up at her beautiful smile and the twinkle in her eye, and as I heard the countless stories of how she elevated the lives of everyone she came into contact with, I wondered how many people in my own life don't truly know how much I love them? Maybe I don't express it, or small grievances get in the way. But I have no doubt that those close to Heidi know and feel how loved they are by her. As one of her friends put it, "she made each of us feel that we were the most important person in the world to her. Because we were." I can't possibly do justice to what I experienced yesterday. Every person who spoke about Heidi was in themselves exceptional, and they were talking about a uniquely exceptional woman. Some of the stories about her were hilarious, and others just made you desperate to know her and be in her presence. I wouldn't try to paraphrase. But I feel blessed to have shared in this small part of her life. I never thought it would be possible to miss someone I never knew, but I miss Heidi. Even though I've only peeked through a small window onto her incredible life, she has taught me more about living and dying than I would have thought imaginable. Now, when I waver or when I'm unsure, I find myself looking toward Heidi and wondering how she'd feel or what she'd do. Suddenly, what is unimportant falls away and what's truly important becomes clear. From having know her even from this distance, I will aspire to be more like her - more loving, more present, more adventurous, more my true self. I'll seize this day to spend time with the people I love, to see them and listen to them with an open heart. And while I wouldn't expect to be in Heidi's league, I'll think of her and try to make my own life and the lives of those around me as rich and as brilliant as possible, today. Liz Dx 12/9/2008, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/8 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Heidi's Memorial Service - October 12, 2009 elizzim AnnaM

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2009 03:47AM elizzim wrote: Natalie, I echo what faithandfifty said...I can't imagine what you must feel when you wake in the morning, when you lay your head down at night, and every moment in between. Pain for your loss, pain for what Heidi went through, and that she is not here with as she so wanted to be. And then again, all the love and beauty that she CONTINUES to create. I was so touched by your having read the posts from this site yesterday, and by the fact that Heidi found comfort and understanding here.  This was my 11 year old daughter Natalie's toast last night at dinner (unprompted): "To Heidi. She's going to have another beautiful life. She's going to spread her joy someplace else. She's going on to make others joyful." And I believe her!
Posts.Title: Heidi's Memorial Service - October 12, 2009 elizzim AnnaM

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2009 06:32PM elizzim wrote: By the way - on a lighter note - Heidi was worried that she wouldn't be "popular" on this site when she came on the scene. Now, how many of us have silently thought that, but would have felt too embarassed to put that thought into words? That's one of the many little stories about Heidi that gives you a sense of how completely delightful she was. Heidi, popular doesn't begin to describe the place you hold around here!
Posts.Title: Heidi's Memorial Service - October 12, 2009 elizzim AnnaM

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2009 07:19PM - edited Jan 14, 2009 07:20PM by elizzim Thank you all SO much for all the input, which helped me know what to expect after my sugery.  As it turned out, I had a terrible reaction to the anesthesia, and had a tough time in the hospital - ended up staying four nights (couldn't eat and was throwing up for 3 full days). But I did finally stabilize and came home Saturday.  I get a little stronger each day. Today, I saw my surgeon, ahd my drains removed and got the path report.  There was a larger tumor in my left breast than had been suspected from biopsy, and my right breast (on which I got a "prophylactic" mastectomy), also had DCIS. Very scary, but confirms that I did the right thing in getting the bilateral mastectomy.  I'm so grateful to say that my sentinel nodes on both sides were clean. That's my update - I'm getting used to this new body, but I feel surprisingly OK on that front. I think my true struggle will be just living each day with the fear of metastasis down the line - I saw my mother go through so much, as I know so many of you here are going through.
Posts.Title: Hello from a NEW member! elizzim elizzim

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2009 12:01PM elizzim wrote: My thoughts have been with Heidi and you, her little brother, and all of you who love her, all through the night. It's hard to believe how much you can be affected by someone you've never actually met. My heart is so heavy today... I am in CT as well, and went to the same hospital as Heidi. I spoke to my two daughters about her last night, and they have Heidi in their prayers. They asked if there was some way to send a card to her children, but I don't know it that's even possible. We would like to do something to show all of you how far Heidi's reach has extended, and how much she is in the hearts of so many.

All of your stories, and your tips, will help me a lot to prepare.  I have two more idiotic questions - idiotic because they seem so trivial in relation to dealing with the diagnosis of cancer and all the uncertainty that follows.  How soon after surgery can you shower?  Also, is it possible to do laundry if you bend, so that you do not have to lift your arms?  I can't imagine how I'll take care of my kids without doing laundry every few days!  Thanks to all of you... I'm getting these issues out of the way, so that I can focus on researching adjuvant therapies, etc.

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2009 09:51PM elizzim wrote: Hi LittleFlower, I just want to tell you that you are not alone - I feel all the same emotions and fears all the time, and I know that in the future, I will struggle with the same reactions to all aches and pains. It's so hard living with that dark cloud. The only thing that really helps, I think, since we can't have the guarantees that we'd like, is to try as much as possible to live in the present moment. If you can manage that whenever possible, your anxiety decreases, too. Is there anyone that you talk to on a regular basis about how to live with this fear? I think it's important to have someone other than family and friends, someone who is yours and yours alone, and with whom you never have to feel bad about venting.  Anyway, I'm thinking of you. -Liz
Posts.Title: hip pain LittleFlower NancyD

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2009 11:55AM elizzim wrote: Margot - I'm connecting your posts on this thread with your posts on the MSK oncologists thread that I began.  We're both being treated at MSK - do you mind my asking where you are located? I understand if you want your privacy, but it would be nice to know that a few of us are in the same general area, and going through similar things, in case we ever want to get together. (I'm in Newtown/Sandy Hook, CT.) Sharon - I similarly noticed that you're in Glastonbury, not terribly far from me. Your positive attitude is so inspiring to me. It's amazing how much you've had to deal with, being BRCA 1+.  I love that you're relentlessly optimistic.  I truly believe that attitude can help w/immunity.  My close friend, who's also a brilliant physician, keeps telling me that.  apfuentes -  I really identify w/everything you said. Is that picture of you with your real (previous) hair, or is that a wig? I guess it's time to invest in some hats - an accessory I never needed before! ('m not much of a baseball cap lady - they look awful on me!) I feel the same way ultimately - whatever it takes to most effectively fight the cancer, I'll do. Being here for my 2 daughters, especially when they have issues w/their Dad, from whom I'm divorced - is all that really matters. For me, it is not a question of whether or not to do chemo.  I know I have a high-grade, aggressive cancer, and I may be BRCA + (still don't know yet).  Also waiting for my Oncotypedx test. I'm pretty certain that chemo will be indicated, and there's no question for me about doing it.  I'm just trying to wrap my mind around this next step in fighting the disease.  I'm still just 2 weeks out from my bilateral mastectomy surgery. I think I'm also struggling with making my way through the world, single, with all this stuff going on!

You must be so proud of her.  And you're right, Deanna, and I know it:  SO worth it to know you've done everything possible to fight the cancer. Part of the problem for me might be that I took care of my Mom as she died of this disease, and she died bald, so I think I associate that with her death. But it's also all tied up with my self-image, which I have to work on.

I met with my oncologist for the first time yesterday, and in some ways I feel MORE confused than ever.  Also, how have you been doing in terms of side effects? Hope you, and all of you, are getting through this OK. -Liz
Posts.Title: Chemo with negative nodes? elizzim dcgirl

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2009 12:42PM - edited Feb 18, 2009 12:46PM by elizzim Hi Ladies, Janet and Lisa, I just read your posts.  Lisa, it's good to hear that your side effects were manageable, and that you remained active throughout treatment. That gives me hope that it won't necessarily be as bad as I've read! Janet - Yes, if I were you I'd opt for chemo. And 45 better be young - I'm 46! I still feel like I'm 28! Well, I am working with the top oncologist at MSK. And he pretty much WOULD NOT LET ME DO THE ONCOTYPE DX TEST!! His reasoning was that I pretty much know I want to do chemo, even if it improves my chance of recurrence only be 3-4%. I just need to know that I've done absolutely everything I can to reduce the risk. And he feels that if I got a high number, it'd tell me nothing I don't already feel; if I got a low or middle-range number, I'd just ignore it because I already know I want chemo. He also - and this is the 1st time I've heard this - expressed reservations about the meaning of the results of this test. I walked away utterly confused - I thought the oncotype test was one of the BEST new tools we've got to fight this disease.  I also would like to know everything there is to know about the characteristics of my cancer, for possible future treatment options, and for my daughters' possible future use. But when I told him that I might just want to have the test done ANYWAY, he told me that he'd talk me out of it!! I basically like this guy, and I know that he has actually been instrumental in much of the research that we're using to structure treatment now...IF I KNOW I WANT CHEMO, DO YOU LADIES THINK THERE'S ANY GOOD REASON TO GET THE ONCOTYPE DX TEST? I'd appreciate any input on this question. I'm starting chemo on Thursday, Feb. 26th. I'm participating in the study where one arm gets 4 X AC, and the other arm gets Taxol, so I don't know which drug I'll be getting.

Posts.Title: Chemo with negative nodes? elizzim dcgirl

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2009 02:19PM elizzim wrote: Margot and Sharon, So nice to receive your posts today. Sharon, I know where Northport is - I'm originally from NY, and I'm somewhat familiar with LI. I'm near exit 10 off of I-84. I have 2 girls, ages 10 and 7. I'm interested to know how you felt after your exchange surgery - did you feel immediate relief from the pressure of the tissue expanders? It's comforting to know that there is, eventually, light at the end of the tunnel. I have a feeling that no matter what stage of treatment you're at, having cancer continues to feel surreal. Sharon, I will definitely update you on my info as things evolve. As far as my surgery goes:  I did have reconstruction w/tissue expanders. They are pretty much constantly uncomfortable (my original fill was 300 cc - lots of pressure, having intermittent trouble getting a deep breath), but overall, I feel surprisingly OK about the mastectomies. My focus is squarely on trying to regain health, as well as trying to gear up for chemo, which I know we all dread. And lastly, my daughters have been truly incredible through all this.  They are amazing souls! I am determined to live to be an old lady in order to be with them. (BTW Sharon, we have a very similar diagnosis. My tumor size was 1.6 cm, everything else is pretty much the same.) I am really touched to have the support of women such as you, who share this experience. Maybe at some point we will meet face to face! Thanks for being there, Liz
Posts.Title: Chemo with negative nodes? elizzim dcgirl

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2009 04:14PM elizzim wrote: Hi Jodie,  I just went to your site and saw your beautiful photos, not to mention accomplishments! This must have been the LAST thing you expected to happen to you. I am from NYC as well, and I'm being treated at MSK. How about you? As devastated as I am (embarrassed by my devastation, too) by the prospect of hair loss, my primary goal is to do EVERYTHING in my power to maximize my chances of a cure. So, I want to do the most aggressive things possible, within the parameters of reason and medical knowledge.  At this point, 30-40% seems like a pretty good bet.  Why are you doing radiation with no (+) nodes? And do you mind my asking where exactly this trial is taking place?
Posts.Title: Chemo with negative nodes? elizzim dcgirl
